title: 108_s1894
content: Interest payments are deductible when a disqualified guarantee has no economic effect. Amendment to Section 163(j)(6)(D)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code allows for exceptions to disqualified guarantees, including guarantees by foreign persons if the taxpayer could have borrowed without the guarantee. The amendments made by this section apply to guarantees issued on and after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 2. Interest paid to certain lenders not disqualified interest. Section 163(j)(3)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new clause stating that interest must not be paid to a qualified lender. Additionally, Section 163(j)(6) defines a qualified lender as a U.S. person subject to income tax. The term 'financial institution' is defined as a person subject to net or gross basis taxation, including those required to include interest on debt in taxable income under section 882. The term 'financial institution' refers to a person engaged in banking, financing, or similar businesses, a corporation described in banking regulations, or an insurance company subject to tax. 'Publicly issued debt' includes commercial paper under specific securities laws. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for a debt instrument to qualify as exempt from withholding tax under certain sections of the Securities Act of 1933. It must be part of an issue meeting specific requirements and be readily tradable on an established securities market. The curr_chunk explains that debt instruments can be exempt from registration under the Securities Act of 1933 if they meet certain criteria, such as being intended for distribution to non-US persons. The amendments made by this section apply to debt issued on or after the enactment of this Act.
